intro: Pinus sylvestris var. pannonica, commonly known as the Hungarian Scots pine, is a subspecies of the Scots pine native to Central and Eastern Europe. It is characterized by its tall, slender trunk and long, needle-like leaves that are typically 5–10 cm in length. The tree produces cones that are cylindrical and often persist on the branches for several years. It thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to temperate climates with cold winters. This subspecies is valued for its ecological role and is also used in reforestation efforts.
